msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 204/110

summary.seg: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 204/110 (hereafter MS 204/110) is a composite manuscript with the complexities of its production and use visible through every page of the small volume. MS 204/110 is now better known as the Vetus liber archidiaconi eliensis (The Old Book of the Archdeacons of Ely) and consists of various records and administrative notes of the archdeacons of Ely and members of their administrative office from the 13th to the 16th centuries, with the majority of the volume originating in the 13th century and being continually added to by subsequent scribes. Although the volume is now bound in an attractive binding probably added in the 17th century, the frequently stained and damaged leaves and the small format of the quires are testament to the former administrative use of the gatherings within.

MS 204/110 was given to Gonville and Caius as part of the bequest of William Moore Moore, William (b. ?1590 - d. 1659) a manuscript collector and former fellow of Gonville and Caius College (c. 1615-1647). Moore resigned or was ejected from his fellowship in 1647, but by 1653 he had been appointed University Librarian and he remained in that position until his death in 1659, at which time, his personal book collection passed to his former College. Unfortunately, little is known about where Moore obtained the majority of his manuscripts and so their provenance can only be inferred through indirect evidence (see Pouzet 2017). In the case of MS 204/110, the book was presumably the property of the archdeacons from its creation in the 13th century, but whether it passed to Moore as a direct purchase from the diocese of Ely, or whether it passed through private ownership in the late 16th and early 17th centuries before finding its way into Moore's collection is unclear.

MS 204/110 is full of the names of individuals who are otherwise unknown to the historical record, but one former user of the book may have been
Rowland Taylor Taylor, Rowland, ?-1555 who was executed as a Protestant martyr in Aldham Common, near Hadleigh in Suffolk in 1555. There is a signature on p. 1, 'Rolandus Tayler officialis' in ink in a hastily written 16th century hand - Feltoe and Minns in their generally masterful edition of MS 204/110 noted the Rowland Taylor annotation, but did not consider the Rowland Taylor who was martyred in 1555 to be a credible candidate for identification with this annotation as they dated the hand to the 15th century, and apparently did not know of Taylor's role in the diocese of Ely. J. S. Craig wrote about Taylor's life and career and brought to light Taylor's appointment as an official of the archdeacon of Ely from c. 1539, but did not know of MS 204/110. Taken together, the signature on p. 1 and Craig's work that independently shows Taylor's role within the diocese, it is strongly probable that the signature on p. 1 is that of Rowland Taylor, the Protestant reformer and preacher who was executed in 1555.

Much of the content of MS 204/110 is administrative in nature and one of the largest sequences of records, from pp. 55-125 concerns the inventories of churches and chapels within the Ely deaneries, their rents owed, and whether they were to be appropriated from other jurisdictions. The core of the inventories was begun by the earliest group of scribes who worked on the volume (the 'A Group' as assigned by Feltoe and Minns) who worked c. 1277-1278 to c. 1284, and then these inventories and parish records were constantly updated by members of the office of the archdeacon as new surveys were done and new administrative arrangements were applied to the parishes.

In addition to all of the administrative records, there is a medical recipe on p. 42, containing a version of the recipe for eye problems supposedly created for King Edward I by Nicholas de Tyngewick. There is another version of the recipe in another Curious Cures manuscript, Cambridge, St John's College, MS E.6, 'Thomas Betson's Notebook', f. 107r, ln. 9 seq , although in the St John's manuscript, the recipe is incorrectly stated to have been developed for King Edward III by de Tyngewick. Master Nicholas de Tyngewick is a relatively well-attested figure, who is known to have taken care of King Edward I when he became sick while staying at Lanercost Priory in 1306. Other than the discrepancy over which King Edward the recipe was developed for, the versions in MS 204/110 and Cambridge, St John's College MS E.6 are remarkably similar, and list the majority of their plants and the processing methods in the same order, which shows that there was good stability in the transmission of even ephemeral medical recipes (i.e., not ones that belonged to the big Salernitan receptaria) in late medieval England, as the MS 204/110 version of the recipe was probably copied in the late 14th century, and the St John's College version dates from the early 16th century.

foliation.note: Paginated in light brown ink in a ?16th century hand in the upper outer corner of each recto. In order to produce a functional TEI-XML catalogue record, the paper endleaves were assigned page designations [i]-[iv] and [v]-[viii], and these designations are enclosed in [square brackets] throughout the record.

Foliated in dark ink in a ?late 15th or ?early 16th century hand in the centre of the lower margin of each recto of the present pp. 3-43. The folio designations no longer appear in the correct sequence and 'f. 13' (the present pp. 25-26) appears before 'f. 12' (the present pp. 27-28).

collation.p:
This is a composite manuscript with a complex codicological presentation and the collation cannot be established with absolute certainty due to the informal establishment of the volume, the loss of several leaves, and the tightness of the present binding. The structure of the volume appears to be as follows:
Parchment endleaf (pp. 1-2) |
Parchment endleaf (pp. 3-4 3-4) +
Quire 14 (pp. 5-12)
Quire 28-1 + 1 (pp. 13-28; original 8th leaf missing, the current 7th leaf is a singleton and was originally a replacement 8th leaf, but was taken down and incorrectly remounted so that it is now the 7th leaf in the quire)
Quire 36 (pp. 29-40)
Quire 4?4-1 (pp. 41-46; 3 leaves remain)
Quire 54 (pp. 47-54)
Quire 66 (pp. 55-66)
Quire 7?10 (pp. 67-84; 9 leaves remain)
Quire 88 (pp. 85-100)
Quire 98 (pp. 101-116)
Quire 106 (pp. 117-128) |
Quire 116-1 (pp. 129-138; 6th lost) |
Quire 12?10-4 (pp. 139-150; stubs visible for original first and second leaf, original 9th and 10th also gone)
Quire 132 (pp. 151-154)
Quire 1410 (pp. 155-174)
Quire 154 (pp. 175-182)
Quire 16?6-1 (pp. 183-192; 5 leaves remain)
Quire 178 (pp. 193-208)
Quire 186 (pp. 209-220)
Quire 194 (pp. 221-228)
collation.formula: Two parchment endleaves + 14 28-1 + 1 (original 8th leaf missing, the 7th a singleton and incorrectly remounted before the 8th) 36 4?4-1 54 66 7?10 88 98 106 116-1 (6th lost) 12?10-4 132 1410 154 16?6-1 178 186 194

signatures.p: No medieval leaf signatures common to the entire volume.
No quire signatures common to the entire volume.

handDesc.summary: Due to the accumulative, vade mecum nature of the booklets in the volume, several of the hands in this manuscript appear in several Parts of the manuscript. Feltoe and Minns produced an inventory of the main scribes and assigned them to six roughly chronological groups (A-F) and their inventory of the hands is summarised below. The 'A Group' are the original hands which wrote the Inventories of churches and made brief mention of quasi-parochial chapels of Newton, Coton and Steeple Morden; Feltoe and Minns determined that the 'A Group' were probably active c. 1277-1278 and before 1284 at the latest due to the combinations of events referred to in their stints. The 'B Group' as determined by Feltoe and Minns denotes 'the first layer of additions between the compiling of the lists c. 1278 and the appearance of Ralph de Fodringhey's dated entries in 1304'. According to Feltoe and Minns, stints by the 'B Group' includes the Inventories of Howes and Benwich chapels and other chapels including Linton, Kneesworth, Royston, Redreth, Emneth, Whittlesey St Andrew, Benwick and March, as well as most of the notes about summonses. The 'C Group' were determined by Feltoe and Minns to be the group of scribes connected with Ralph de Foderinghey's activities c. 1304-1316. The 'D Group' as determined by Feltoe and Minns is small, just two scribes, and Feltoe and Minns suggest the possibility that the 'D Group' is actually just one scribe with a rather loose and careless aspect. The 'D Group' always follows work by Scribe C2 and was probably active around and shortly after 1320 as it mentions Thomas de Abinton as Vicar of St Botolph's Cambridge who succeeded to that role c. 1320. The 'E Group' as determined by Feltoe and Minns consists of two scribes seemingly active in the middle of the 14th century before 1351. According to Feltoe and Minns it is 'very hard to draw the line' between the 'E' and 'F' Groups. The 'F Group' consists of the final group of scribes working on the manuscript who had probably ceased their activities by 1401 at the latest. Readers of this record are encouraged to consult Feltoe and Minns, esp. pp xxxiii-xxxvi for further information.

handNote.p: Scribe A1 is the 'main hand' of the Inventories of churches found on pp. 55-125. Scribe A1 must have been working before 1284 at the latest as he copied a note about St Peter extra portam (now St Mary the Less) as belonging to St John's Hospital and not to Peterhouse, under whose jurisdiction it fell after 1284.
Scribe A2 is an untidy hand responsible for the entry on Barton p. 95.
Scribe A3 is responsible for pp. 117-122.
Scribe A4 is responsible for the entry on Wilburton and Chatteris on p. 123 which mentions the Visitation of 1278.
Scribe A5 is responsible for the entry on Whittlesey St Mary on p. 124.
Scribe A° is responsible for p. 46. Scribe A°'s work is badly damaged through rubbing, and Feltoe and Minns caution that Scribe A° might actually be a hand belonging to Group B.
Scribe B1 occurs over erasures on pp. 80-84, 106 123, and 124. Scribe B1 also seems to be responsible for entries on 'fresh' surfaces on p. 100, and the beginning of the list of chapelries on p. 52.
Scribe B2 is responsible for entries on pp. 123 and 125. Feltoe and Minns describe Scribe B2 as the 'most characteristic [of the B group]'.

Scribe B3 'may be more than one hand' according to Feltoe and Minns and 'generally presents the first additions made to a list, but follows B1 and B2'. An example of Scribe B3's work appears in the text for Linton
Scribe B4 has 'a rather ornamental hand of rare occurence' according to Feltoe and Minns. Scribe B4 occurs on p. 58, 89 and 102.
Scribe C1 is respobsible for entries dated during Ralph de Fodringhey's activities and copied notes on Tydd on p. 108 and Wendy p. 101 dated to 1304 and 1305 respectively.
Scribe C2 is present throughout the Inventories and includes dates from 1304-1311; according to Feltoe and Minns, the hand 'varies a great deal'.

Scribe D1 is present throughout the Inventories and always follows Scribe C2. According to Feltoe and Minns, Scribe D1 is capable of writing with an 'elaborate' and a 'careless' aspect, although Feltoe and Minns go on to say that the two forms may in fact reflect the work of two different scribes. Scribe D1 was probably active around and shortly after 1320 as it mentions Thomas de Abinton as Vicar of St Botolph's Cambridge who succeeded to that role c. 1320.

Scribe D2 is 'the most ambitious hand in the book, though very uneven [...], but it can be recognised by a curious yellow ink and the spelling spalterium'. Feltoe and Minns say that D2's hand 'recalls the hand in which the Advocates' names are entered in 1306 p. 43, but the dates hardly allow of an identification'.

Scribe D3 is not a designation assigned by Feltoe and Minns, but their survey of the hands in Gonville and Caius MS 204/110 includes a reference in the 'D Group' discussion to 'the mention of T. de Pateshall at Granchester (1324-1331), p. 95, [...] made in a hand which does not recur.'

Scribe E1, according to Feltoe and Minns, 'also uses bright yellow ink' and is 'only concerned with appropriations and procurations, Cambridge All SS. ad Castrum, St Sepulchre, St Michael, St Mary, St Peter extra portam, Abington Great and Little, Barrington and Trumpington. The latter gives 1344 as a terminus post quem. It does not give the appropriation of Whaddon in 1351 or Litlington in 1358.

Scribe E2 is 'a curious back-sloping hand' that records the appropriation of Litlington to Clare Hall and a fair number of additions. Feltoe and Minns think that Scribe E2 also seems to recur in some of the model letters from the official on pp. 185-191.
Scribe F1 has a 'coarse' hand according to Feltoe and Minns.
Scribe F2 has a 'light' hand according to Feltoe and Minns and 'seems to have copied the Constitution on p. 128, perhaps the memorandum dated 1386 on p. 127.'
Scribe F3 has a 'cursive' hand according to Feltoe and Minns.
Scribe F4 occurs on p. 64 and the entries on pp. 127-128 dated 1383 and 1389.
Scribe F5 supplies 'the appropriations of Long Stanton All SS. (p. 86) in 1380 and Pampisford dated 1387 (p. 79).

binding.p: ?17th century binding. Rebacked. Fully bound in leather over wood boards with matching blind-tooled decoration to front and rear covers. A decorative roll of alternate ovals and maltese crosses present at the perimeter of the boards. A narrow dotted single-fillet frame with Oxford corners inset from the perimeter of the boards by c. 15 mm and enclosing a large centre panel. The centre panel is filled with concentric frames formed with an arcaded roll (c. 8mm wide) with a stylised fleur-de-lis motif in each arcade; the concentric arcade-rolls continue inward until a small rectangular inner panel of c. 20x80mm (w x h) remains at the centre of the cover. A small ?daisy fleuron impressed at each corner of the small inner panel.
The rear cover is damaged with a number of small straight and lunate marks and gouges, perhaps indicating chained storage at an earlier time.

Four raised bands on the spine. Spine is capped at head and tail, and no head or tail tabs or bands are visible. A title for the the volume tooled in gold on the spine: 'VETUS LIBER ELIENSIS'. Two small printed paper labels fixed to the spine '204' in black and '110' in red for the present shelfmark.
The cover leather over the head, fore, and tail edges of the boards decorated with a gilded geometric roll (not photographed).
Paper pastedowns pasted over the turn ins. The front pastedown contains a Gonville and Caius College bookplate, the rear pastedown is blank.
There are two paper endleaves at each end of the volume, pp. [i]-[iv] and [v]-[viii]. Page [iv] contains a note in ink in an ?18th century hand describing the contents of the volume.
There is no information available about when the volume was rebacked.

Evidence of a former binding present in the form of rust staining and damage in the centre of the outer margin of pp. 1-2; this type of damage is typically caused by a metal fastening across the fore edge of the volume.

provenance.p:
Owned by William Moore (b. ?1590 - d. 1659 Moore, William (b. ?1590 - d. 1659) a manuscript collector and former fellow of Gonville and Caius College (c. 1615-1647). The manuscript appears in Moore's catalogue of his collection as 'A 27' with the following description:
'1. Liber Archidiaconatus Eliensis in pergamena in quo continentur multa ad Academiam Cantabrig. Spectantia
2. Statuta Synodalia au£toritate Episco. Eliensis
3. Compositio inter Episcop Eliensem et Acad. Cantabrigiensem 1276
4. Taxatio Parochiarum Dioces. Eliens.
5. Iuramentum Commissio et Mag. Glomeriae
6. Tenor Laudi Lati per Archiep. Catuar inter Episcop. Eliens. et Archidiaconum'

acquisition.p: Given to Gonville and Caius c. 1659 by William Moore Moore, William (b. ?1590 - d. 1659) a manuscript collector and former fellow of Gonville and Caius College (c. 1615-1647). Moore resigned or was ejected from his fellowship in 1647, but by 1653 he had been appointed University Librarian and he remained in that position until his death in 1659. Moore died in 1659 and left his personal collection of c. 150 manuscripts to Gonville and Caius.

For further information about Moore see:
Venn/ACAD MR606W2 (or Venn, I. 192) ODNB DOI: 10.1093/ref:odnb/19152

note.p: On p. 1 the words 'Blomf.1727. Extr', this is a reference to some extracts made from the volume by the antiquarian Francis Blomefield Francis Blomefield (d. 1752) who obtained a BA from Gonville and Caius in 1727 and made a series of extracts from this manuscript into some of his personal notebooks. The extracts are likely to be among Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Gough Camb. 48-50

On p. 1, the words 'Rolandus Tayler officialis' in ink in a 16th century hand. It is very likely that the 'Rolandus Tayler' who signed his name is the the Rowland Taylor Taylor, Rowland, ?-1555 who was executed as a Protestant martyr in 1555. Taylor was ordained exorcist and acolyte in 1528, and was an Official of the archdeacon of Ely from c. 1539 (see Craig, 1999).

Feltoe and Minns first deciphered the Rowland Taylor annotation, but did not consider the Rowland Taylor who was martyred in 1555 to be a credible candidate for identification with this annotation as they dated the hand to the 15th century, and apparently did not know of Taylor's role in the diocese of Ely.

Feltoe and Minns determined that this note referred to a chantry founded in 1445 in the south side of the chancel at Borough Green by the D Burgh family. See Feltoe and Minns p. 215 for more information.

Muscas et mures febres fratres quoque fures
In mundo plures deus hos confundere cures
Musca mouet mentem facit herum flectere flere
Vix vadit in ventrem nisi vertat viscera vere
Sic fratres fatui dominos dominant dominanti
ac incensati famulos frangunt infatuati
vnde ad ephesios legatur fratres nolumos vos
Si carmelite veniant dic omnibus ite
si predicatores stent foras ante fores
si sint minores hiis nullos ergo datores
nec augustinis hos cede tere minis
pauper vexatus peregrans puer et ceteratus
prengans vagantes non peccant bis comedentes

msItem.title: Extract from a letter advocating for people to be able to make their wills without interference or pressure to make particular bequests

note.p: This text seems to be part of a letter composed by Ralph de Fodringhey, archdeacon of Ely c. 1288-1316, advocating for people whether they are freemen, villeins, unfree or any other status ('liberos ascripticios servos vel alios') to be able to make their wills without interference or pressure to make particular bequests.
The text is followed by words in a late 14th century hand, 'Est mea mens mota pro te speciosa'.
According to Feltoe and Minns this text is copied in a 'C Group' hand.

listBibl.bibl: Fully transcribed in Feltoe and Minns, p. 17

note.p:
Page 42, full transcription:
Est quedam aqua nobilis pro omni vicio oculorum que quidem aqua . Dominus Rex Edwardus pater utebatur per consilium magistri Nicholai de Tyngewyco et aliorum medicorum peritissimorum . R . T . herbarum feniculi rute eufrasie . veruene . Tormentille betonice rubre rostri porcinisowethistil gallatriciioculus christi ipiechekynmete pimpernelle rubre donie pionie filaginis foliorum vitis apii ... nie caprifolijwodebynde . ana . prima die trite ponantur in albo secunda die in urina pueri masculi et virginis tercia die in lacte mulieris Quarta die in bono . et tunc postea distillentur in aqua. Hinc custodiatur in vase vitreo quia est aquarum nobilissima pro omni causa
According to Feltoe and Minns this text may have been copied by Scribe F1.

Another version of this recipe in Cambridge, St John's College, MS E.6, 'Thomas Betson's Notebook', f. 107r, ln. 9 seq . The Cambridge, St John's College, MS E.6 version of the recipe is transcribed in J. Adams, and S. Forbes (eds.), The Syon Abbey Herbal: The Last Monastic Herbal in England, c. AD 1517: From St. John’s College, Cambridge Manuscript 109 (E.6) (London: AMCD, 2015), p. 279. Adams and Forbes read the initial of the medical practitioner's name in the St John's College MS as a 'W' and expanded the name as 'Willelmi', but the initial in Cambridge, St John's College MS E.6 is 'N' and should be expanded to 'Nicholai, in agreement with the name in Gonville and Caius MS 204/110. A Nicholas de Tyngewick (Tingewick) was a royal physician to King Edward I abd provided significant treatment when the king was taken ill at Lanercost Priory in 1306; Tyngewick was later associated with the royal court of King Edward II - see C. H. Talbot, and E. A. Hammond, The Medical Practitioners in Medieval England : A Biographical Register (London: Wellcome Historical Medical Library, 1965).
Similar recipe in Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.8.12, f. i (front pastedown)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition. Some text illegible due to abrasion and staining.

p.seg: Most pages are unruled, but where ruling is present (e.g., p. 119, frame and lines, leadpoint) it is not part of a significant programme of layout standardisation. Leaves have varying numbers of lines and varying 'text block' sizes due to the substantial number of scribes who added notes to the quire booklets.

handNote.p: See general description of hands adapted from Feltoe and Minns above. Notes about individual scribes are recorded against each msItem, and identifications made by Feltoe and Minns are described as such.

decoNote.p: Sketch of a ?tonsured head in profile facing left in upper margin of p. 99.

note.p: Page 3: Note in ink in a 16th century hand, 'Iste liber pertinet ad archdiaconum Eliensis Cum Gaudio magno et honore'.
Page 3: A note twice in ink in ?16th century hands, 'To have ye copie of Thomas Hammondis wyll of Whaddoni'. Whaddon is probably the village of that name in Cambridgeshire
Page 3: Note in ink in a ?17th century hand, 'Liber Archidiaconatus Eliensis'

Page 4: miscellanous annotations in every orientation in ink in several hands, including the following
The name Richard Kyllyngworth Richard Killingworth several times. This may be the Richard Killingworth who died c. 1586 and who owned Balsham Place Manor in Cambridgeshire and several other manors in East Anglia; Venn has several members of the University of Cambridge in the late 16th and early 17th centuries with the surname 'Killingworth' who originated from Cambridgeshire villages.
The personal or place name 'Kymbolton' several times. There is a Kimbolton in Cambridgeshire to which this note may refer
A note, 'demonium habet'
A note, perhaps belonging with 'demonium habet', 'rumpetur turma malorum'
The personal or place name 'Lumley'
'Cantebr Brune et Shynge
Episcopatus'

origin.origDate: The oldest texts in this Part were written in the final quarter of the 13th century, and the leaves were added to throughout the 14th and 15th century by multiple scribes.
origin.origPlace: Written in England, probably within the medieval diocese of Ely.

note.p: Date of production assigned based on palaeographical features and dates within the texts. Place of production assigned based on palaeographical features and names and places mentioned within the texts.

provenance.p: Owned and used by members of the office of the Archdeacon of Ely between the 13th and 15th centuries.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius, MS 204/110, pp. 129-138

note.p: Leaves from a manuscript calendar arranged a month-per-page; the final page, and thus the final two months (November and December) missing.
Late 12th or early 13th century calendar with frequent additions in 13th, 14th, and 15th century hands.
The word 'pape' (Pope) in commemorations struck through with brown ink, e.g., p. 131 'Gregorij pape' for Pope Gregory's commemmoration on 12 March.
Some feasts erased, see e.g., p. 132 on the lines for the 9th and 10th of April

Note on the Battle of Agincourt (25 October 1415) added to the lower margin of p. 138 in an English cursiva hand, now very faint, full transcription:
'Bellum de Agincourt fuit in die Crispini et Crispiniani in Picardia per Henricum quintum Regem Anglie Anno domini mmo ccccmo xvto in die veneris'

Poem on the 'Egyptian days' added with a line-per-month around the 'KL' cipher on each page, the full poem as follows:
Prima dies iani . septenaque detur inani
Quarta refutatur febrim . quam terna sequatur
Prima necat martis . simul huius quarta fit artis
Denus undenus est mortis vulnere plenus
Tercius occidit et septimus ora relidit
Denus et ipse furit . quindenus iunius urit
Ter decimus nutat iulii . decimusque salutat
Prima dat augustum . de fine secunda perustum
Tercia Septembris et denus fert mala membris
Terna subit latebras . octobris dena tenebras

listBibl.bibl: Notable additions to the calendar discussed in M. R. James, Catalogue Vol. I, no. 204, pp. 236-237
Fully transcribed in Feltoe and Minns, pp. 151-160

p.secFol: 131: Prima necat Martis simul huius quarta fit artis

collation.p:
A damaged quire, probably 6 leaves originally, the last now missing:
Quire 116-1 (pp. 129-138; 6th leaf lost)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition. Leaves in this Part have minor dirt and stains, but most text is legible. The title 'Pape' has been struck out with ink on most calendar entries for the commemorative feasts of the various former Popes. Leaves have been trimmed with minor losses to decoration and annotation, see e.g., upper edge of p. 136.

p.seg: Standard calendar layout of one-month-per-page with columns left to right for golden numbers, dominical letters, Roman calendar reckoning, and commemorative feasts.

handNote.p: The original core of the calendar is written in a northern textalis libraria, and there are additions in several 13th=15th century hands .

decoNote.p: Flourished initials in the 'Arabesque' style with stylised floral and foliate flourishes in red or blue ink for the 'KL' in the upper register of each calendar page.
Calendar headings, dominical letters, Roman calendar reckoning, and particular feasts and astronomical events written in red or blue ink.

origin.origDate: Original calendar entries written in the late 12th century or in the 13th century.
origin.origPlace: Written in England, probably at Barnwell Priory, on the eastern edge of Cambridge.

note.p: Date of production assigned based on palaeographical features. Place of production assigned based on palaeographical features and commemorative feasts. M. R. James suggested that the calendar could perhaps be localised to Barnwell on the eastern edge of Cambridge as the calendar entry for 28 August (p. 136) is for the commemmoration of 'Augustini patris nostri', (Augustine, our Father) and Barnwell was one of the most prominent Augustinian houses within the Diocese of Ely.

listBibl.bibl: M. R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Gonville and Caius College, 2 vols (Cambridge, 1917), vol I, no. 204

N. R. Ker, Medieval Libraries of Great Britain: A List of Surviving Books, Royal Historical Society Guides and Handbooks, 3, 2nd edn (London: Offices of the Royal Historical Society, 1964), see p. 7, 'Barnwell'

list.item: Quire 12?10-4 (pp. 139-150; stubs visible for original first and second leaf, original 9th and 10th also gone)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition. Some text illegible due to abrasion and staining.

p.seg: Leaves are typically written in single-column format, often to the extreme outer edge of the leaf. Leaves have varying numbers of lines and varying 'text block' sizes due to the substantial number of scribes who added notes to the quire booklets. Some of the leaves in Quire 14 (pages 174) are frame-ruled, but the leaves have been used for informal annotations rather than ruled and used for substantial texts.

handNote.p: See general description of hands adapted from Feltoe and Minns above. Notes about individual scribes are recorded against each msItem, and identifications made by Feltoe and Minns are described as such.

decoNote.p: Notarial mark without name or initials on p. 182. Possible notary signature in erasure underneath the mark. In addition to the main mark, there are further sketches and partial attempts at the mark on the leaf, not all in the same hand or ink.
Two sketches of hooded medieval male busts (facing R) in hoods on p. 182.

note.p: Page 142: the name 'Jhon Skyl' in ink in a very loose medieval cursive hand.
Page 142: a note in Latin 'pasca nostrum immolatus est Cristus' in ink.
Page 142: five-line music stave with notes drawn in a 'u' shape, no clear melodic pattern discernable
Page 158: note in ink - 'nouerint Vniuersi per presentes me Wyllhelmum Soustons'
Page 163: note in ink in a ?16th century hand - 'John King est uerus possessor huius libri'
Page 172: the names 'Jhon Skyll' and 'Francis Salparwyk' in ink
Page 226: the name 'John Chapman' and a notarial mark in ink, perhaps the scribe of the oath of obedience above
Page 227: annotation in ink - 'inhibitus 5 Septembris 1546'
Page 228: name in ink in a humanist minuscule written upside down relative to the orientation of the codex - 'Thomas Smythe'.
Page 228: name in ink in a humanist minuscule written upside down relative to the orientation of the codex - 'Chapman'.
Page 228: annotation in ink in a humanist minuscule written upside down relative to the orientation of the codex - 'Homo est animal rationale'.

origin.origDate: The oldest texts in this Part were written in the final quarter of the 13th century, and the leaves were added to throughout the 14th and 15th century by multiple scribes.
origin.origPlace: Written in England, probably within the medieval diocese of Ely.

note.p: Date of production assigned based on palaeographical features and dates within the texts. Place of production assigned based on palaeographical features and names and places mentioned within the texts.

provenance.p: Owned and used by members of the office of the Archdeacon of Ely between the 13th and 15th centuries.

revisionDesc.change: 2024-08-30: Draft record prepared by Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries Project, Cambridge University Library
